column1: #Text=Various polycrystalline MgB2 samples are synthesized by solid-state route using ingredients of Mg and B.
#Text=The Mg powder used is from Reidel-de-Haen of assay 99%, insoluble in HCl and with Fe impurity of less than 0.05%.
#Text=B powder is amorphous and Fluka make of assay 95-97%.
#Text=For high superconducting performance of MgB2 the nanoadditives used are nano-SiC (size 10-20 nm) and nano-diamond (size 7-10 nm).
#Text=For individual sample, well-mixed and pelletized rectangular MgB2 pellet is put in an Alumina boat placed inside a soft Fe-tube.

#Text=The encapsulated system is heated in the temperature range from 800 0C to 900 0C for one to three hours in flow of Argon gas at ambient pressure and subsequently allowed to cool to room temperature in same atmosphere.
#Text=The Fe-encapsulation is not kept in direct touch of the raw MgB2 pellet and its both ends are open for the continuous passage of Argon gas.
#Text=The resultant sample is a bulk polycrystalline black compound.
#Text=We also synthesized MgB2 by vacuum annealing method.
#Text=Pure phase MgB2 can be synthesized in oxygen free environment from 700 0C to 1400 0C, respectively in vacuum (10-5 torr) to high pressure of Argon gas [24, 25].
#Text=In this case the Fe tube, which contains the raw MgB2 pellet inside, was sealed inside a quartz tube at high vacuum of 10-5 Torr.
#Text=The encapsulated raw MgB2 pellet is than heated at desired heating temperatures (750 0C) with a hold time (3 hours) and is finally quenched in liquid nitrogen (LN2) [26,27].

#Text=However we realized that the vacuum annealing method results in highly porous samples [28], which in turn adversely affect the transport properties like electrical and thermal conduction, in particular.
#Text=The effects of porosity, crystallization and alignment of grains on various physical properties of MgB2 are previously discussed in a topical review by John M Rowell [29].
